That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Motion (by Mr Fairbairn) proposed: That the Bill be now read a third time.

talk.start.para: - I want to raise a question I mentioned in the course of my earlier remarks. The Commonwealth is providing $4m for this particular project which is to cost $4.2m. I would like to know, if the Minister can give me the information, what criterion is adopted by him or his Department in determining the amount of a grant made to such projects. For some projects the grant represents 45% of the total cost. In this case the grant absorbs almost the entire cost of the project. Is there any fixed rule laid down for the guidance of the Government as to the sum made available?

{2.28 a.m.] - There is no criterion. We are dealing with a basic amount of $50m. We know that if we provide a grant almost identical to the estimated cost of this dam in Victoria it could well be that it will be finished for a cost of $4m. If there are good conditions and a good contract we often find that the cost can be slightly reduced. The Victorian Government said it had two projects which were very similar. It said: 'If the Commonwealth picks up the tab for one project we will be able to afford to proceed with the other'. The two projects were those on the King River and the Mitchell River. The Victorian Government, having ample loan funds available, said that if we advanced the money for one project it would be able to afford the other. In this case we said that we would provide $4m, which was slightly less than the estimated cost of the King River project.

- I would like to ask the Minister a question supplementary to that asked by the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Luchetti). I am not clear on what the Minister meant about additional projects which might be announced. The impression I gained was that it was up to the State Governments to make a further request for funds. Would it not be implicit that they do seek more funds because of the fact that already they have made requests relating to 32 projects? I realise that only a small number of those projects have been analysed. On the other hand, does it mean that those 32 projects have been rejected and that the States have to make further requests? If the Commonwealth is prepared to engage in additional projects, does this mean that we have to push the point with the State Governments that they had better get in fast and make further requests; or does it mean that these requests are now under consideration by the Government?

speech.para: In some cases, particularly so far as Queensland is concerned, projects such as the Burnett River Dam-

talk.start.para: -Order! The debate on the third reading is a very limited debate. I have been very lenient with both the honourable member for Macquarie and the honourable member for Dawson. I would request the honourable member for Dawson to limit his remarks.
- I assume that the Queensland Government would not have to apply again for the Burnett project, because after all it is an urgent project about which a lot has been said in recent weeks.

speech.para: Mr FAIRBAIRN (Farrer- Minister for National Development) {2.31 a.m.] - I feel that we are a little bit like Oliver coming back and asking for a second helping of porridge. We have just got through $50m. No sooner have we allocated this lot than we are being asked where the next lot will come from. Naturally the Commonwealth keeps all requests from the States under review. We have had a further request just recently with regard to the Kolan scheme, which was mentioned by the honourable member for Dawson (Dr Patterson). This will be processed in the normal way. As far as the national water resources development programme is concerned our first commitment has been honoured, but this does not mean that we will drop everything now. We will be reassessing various other projects that have been put to us. But I say that at the present time we have honoured our commitment. We have more than honoured it. Nevertheless if we get future requests from the States we will look at them, and we will look at the request we have already received from Queensland.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

subdebateinfo.title: Maxwell Newton Pty Ltd - Australian Broadcasting Commission - Communism

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Mr Erwin) proposed:

quote.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: - I want to read quickly an extract from the transcript of 'This Day Tonight' on Friday, 21st March, in regard to Mr Maxwell Newton, lt reads:

quote.para: HUDSON: You are extracting then economic information for example to the advantage of private individuals and companies.
NEWTON: Indeed, that's my business. My business is to find out economic and political information before any else . . . publish it and that's how I earn my living.
HUDSON: By fair means or foul.
NEWTON: 1 penetrate the Government.
HUDSON: By any means then.
NEWTON: As best I can.
HUDSON: What sort of government departments then have you penetrated in this way?
NEWTON: The Department of Trade . . . The Department of Trade each week. I publish documents, including confidential documents, from the Department of Trade often verbatim.
HUDSON: There is a suggestion here of course that you'd have to pay for this kind of information.
NEWTON: Well I wouldn't like to comment on that.

speech.para: I consider that Mr Maxwell Newton convicts himself out of his own mouth, and I think it is time that he was brought to the bar of this House.

I want to speak more particularly tonight in regard to Communism and how it is being assisted by the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I wonder if we are correct in subsidising such instrumentalities and authorities as the Australian Broadcasting Commission, which is sabotaging our national heritage, standards and values. There are hundreds of instances that I could reveal, but 1 would quote a revolting programme produced on a Sunday morning just after 'Divine Service' in which the institution of marriage was ridiculed. As unwholesome as that was it was insignificant compared to what was to follow. A frequent exchange of spouses was recommended and justified by the dialogue that followed. The children and the spouses were to continue to live in the same residence - something akin to animals in the field. In order to identify the children with their sire and dam it would have been necessary, I take it, to have had each child earmarked and tattoo branded.

However, what I want to bring forward tonight is the partiality and slant to Communism and extreme left wing politics as featured on two interviews last week. Messrs Joyce and Couchman interviewed Mr Fowler of the Metal Trades Employers Federation. He was interviewed aggressively. The interviewers clearly exhibited where their sympathies lay - certainly not with Mr Fowler. Then last Wednesday we had the spectacle of the same two men interviewing Mr O'Shea at a Peking Commo grog-up. They clearly entered into the festivities and were more delighted than the Peking Communists with Mr O'Shea's release. This was in marked contrast with the interview of Mr Fowler.

Further I want to recall a most treacherous and damnable statement by Mr Duckmanton, in which he stated that if the ABC was to wait to get all people interested and\/or being challenged to appear on a programme simultaneously few programmes would be produced. Radio and television audiences are different from readers of newspapers. If a person is attacked in a newspaper he can reply the following day and 90% of the readers will read his defence and rebuttal and so make their own assessment. He will have been afforded a chance to clear his name or to erase the stigma that has been placed upon him. That is not so, however, on television and radio. Once a person's name is defamed or smeared, it is practically impossible for him to adequately clear his name of the stigma and smears implied, because the members of audiences are never the same. Mr Duckmanton, judging by his statements, could not care less. He flouts what Shakespeare wrote years ago, namely: 'He that filches from me my good name robs me of that which not enriches him, and makes me poor indeed'.

There has been a deterioration in the standard of management and control of the ABC since Mr Duckmanton became General Manager. The sooner he is relieved of his position, the better it will be for the ABC, the nation and broadcasting in particular. Sir Robert Madgwick is a charming and delightful academic gentleman, but he is totally unsuited to the position to which he has been appointed. The people of this nation should be alerted to the seriousness and power of Communism. The Communists are small in number, but their power and strength are truly a threat to Australia.

The set of strikes that has occurred over recent months was initiated in February last by Mr Aarons, the Secretary of the Communist Party. With Russia establishing bases east of Suez and warships in the Indian Ocean, it is our responsibility and our duty to warn the public of the power and strength of the enemy within Australia. These people are small in number, but are aided and abetted, perhaps unwittingly but nevertheless very definitely, by the World Council of Churches. The programming of feature viewing by the ABC does not receive the supervision necessary to ensure that a fair, genuine and balanced programme is televised and broadcast on its various stations.
Question resolved in the affirmative. House adjourned at 2.39 a.m. (Thursday)

debate.para: The following answers to questions upon notice were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for National Development, upon notice:

item.para: Is the Northern Division of his Department making a study of the present and future market prospects for existing crops grown along the Gascoyne River at Carnarvon in Western Australia?
Is the Division also carrying out research for the purpose of recommending future crops for which markets exist?
If so, what stage have the studies reached?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: The State of Western Australia and the Northern Division of my Department are cooperating in an evaluation of the irrigation potential of the Gascoyne River. As part of this evaluation the Northern Division of my Department will in the next few months be undertaking a study of the marketing prospects for crops which may be grown on irrigable land along the Gascoyne River.

The Western Australia State Department of Agriculture is establishing irrigation research trials to provide basic information on the growing of the major crops of the existing plantation area on the inland soils which would be irrigated from the proposed dam. This work is being carried out in conjunction with the Gascoyne Research Station located near Carnarvon.
See 1. and 2. above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for National Development, upon notice:

item.para: Have the Governments of the Commonwealth and the State of Western Australia carried out, or are they now in the process of carrying out, a joint feasibility study of the damming of the Gascoyne River in Western Australia?
If so, what stage has the study reached?
Has any agreement been reached with the Government of Western Australia in relation to Commonwealth financial assistance towards building a dam?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: The State of Western Australia and the Northern Division of my Department are cooperating in an evaluation of the irrigation potential of the Gascoyne River. In regard to the damming of the Gascoyne, the investigations have been carried out by the State.
Surveys and investigations for a major dam in the Kennedy Ranges have been completed to the stage of enabling feasibility studies to proceed.

answer.para: In addition the State of Western Australia has engaged a firm of engineering consultants to study all available information and advise if an interim solution, which will satisfactorily meet the water needs of the existing irrigation lists and of the town, is a possibility.

item.para: No.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice:

quote.para: Are all members of the Commonwealth Parliament covered against the possibility of permanent incapacity by the Parliamentary pension scheme or the Commonwealth Employees' Compensation Act?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Commonwealth Employees' Compensation Act 1930-1969 does not apply to members of Parliament.

The Parliamentary Retiring Allowances Act 1948-1968 does not cover members against the possibility of permanent incapacity as such but in certain circumstances does permit a member who resigns from the Parliament or fails to stand for re-election to be granted a pension after a qualifying period of service shorter than would otherwise be required or to be paid a lump sum benefit greater than that which would otherwise be payable, if the Parliamentary Retiring Allowances Trust is satisfied that the resignation or failure to stand for re-election is due to ill-health.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Labour and National Service, upon notice:

item.para: How many young men have been prosecuted for offences under the National Service Act?
What are the reasons for the prosecutions, and what penalties have been imposed?
How many young men liable to register for national service training have failed to register?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: As at 31st March 1969, there had been 797 convictions for offences under the National Service Act.

Breaches of the National Service Act occur principally in respect of failure to register, to notify change of address, to obey a notice to attend for medical examination, to report for service, to obtain permission to leave Australia, and to produce the certificate of registration to an authorised person. Penalties imposed have been as follows:
Failure to register - 624 convictions - penalties imposed ranged up to $100, more than 50% were of $20 or less.
Failure to notify change of address - 66 convictions - penalties imposed ranged up to $50, approximately 80% were of $20 or less.

Failure to attend medical examination- 46 convictions - monetary penalties imposed ranged up to $100, approximately 60% were of $20 or less; one sentence of 7 days imprisonment as well as a fine following refusal to enter into a recognizance to submit to an examination.

Failure to obey call-up - 33 convictions - 2) were committed to custody of Army including 1.4 who were also fined; 9 entered into a recognizance to obey a further call-up notice including 7 who were also fined; 3 refused to enter into a recognizance to obey a further call-up notice and were sentenced to 2 years' imprisonment. Fines ranged up to $50.
Left Australia without permission - 8 convictions - penalties imposed ranged up to $75, approaching 60% were of $20 or less.
Failure to produce certificate of registration to authorised person - 14 convictions - penalties imposed ranged up to $20.

A further 6 penalties ranging from $6 to $20 were imposed for offences of failure, when temporarily absent from place of living, to make arrangements to ensure that postal communications marked National Service' were received without undue delay, failure to notify loss or destruction of certificate of registration, failure to supply information and supplying false or misleading information.
Despite the efforts of some indivduals and organisations to persuade young men not to register, comparatively few fail to do so.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice:

item.para: Which of the foreign life offices established in Australia are not of a mutual kind?
How many foreign life offices have been established in Australia in each of the last 10 years?

As action has been taken to ensure that no new foreign banks will be established in Australia, why has no action been taken to ensure that no new foreign life offices will be established in Australia?
What income was received in Australia by (a) all life offices and (b) foreign life offices in each of the last 10 years?
What investments were made in Australia by (a) all life offices and (b) foreign life offices in each of the last 10 years?
What action has been taken to ensure thai the income which foreign life offices derive from Australian operations is invested in Australia?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

item.para: See the answer, given today, to Part 1 of Question No. 1259.

The net change in each year since 1960 in the number of predominantly overseas-controlled companies registered under the Life Insurance Act 1945-1965 to carry on life insurance business in Australia has been as follows: 4960 - increase of 7 1961 - increase of 3 1962 - increase of 3 1963 - increase of 1 1964 - no change 1965- increase of 2 1966- no change 1967- decrease of 2 1968 - increase of 6 1969 (to date) - no change.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Navy, upon notice:

item.para: For what reasons and in how many cases do Lieutenants and Sub-Lieutenants receive less pay than the sailors serving with and under them?
What steps are being taken to correct this anomaly?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The introduction in 1968 of the group pay system for sailors, which led to substantial pay increases for many sailors, particularly in the technical grades, has increased temporarily the number of sailors receiving more pay than some junior officers. Overall, there are approximately 2,500 sailors whose rate of pay for the time being exceeds that of Sub-Lieutenant on promotion, and approximately 280 whose rate of pay for the time being exceeds that of a Lieutenant on promotion.

There is nothing unusual in the pay rates of higher technical employments intruding into lower professional salaries. In the case of the Navy, immediately prior to the introduction of group pay, over 800 sailors received rates of pay exceeding that of a Sub-Lieutenant on promotion. The new element in the present situation is that because sailors' rates were increased ahead of the review of officers' rates, the number of sailors receiving pay in excess of some officers' pay is for the present greater.

As the honourable member will realise, the pay of Service officers cannot be considered in isolation, but consideration is being given in the defence group of departments to the question whether the circumstances referred to above are, in the Service situation, sufficiently distinctive to warrant some special amelioratory action.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice:

item.para: Has his attention been drawn to the announcement some weeks ago that the Australian Mutual Provident Society proposes to invest $21m of policy holders' funds in a new building in Sydney?
If so, is it a fact that under the Life Insurance Act a company may include assets in its balance sheet at cost or other valuation?

As the long term trend of real estate and equities is to rise in values, will the Government give consideration to an amendment of the Act to require companies to show such assets at market value in the balance sheet?

Is it a fact that life insurance companies have, over recent years, achieved a very sound and greatly improved financial position? If so, will the Government also give consideration to amending the Act to provide for increased bonuses and higher surrender values to policy holders?
Are the mortality tables that were in use in 1949 still operative, or are the latest and more up-to-date actuarial tables on life expectancy now in use?
What was the interest earning rate on policy holders' funds in 1949, and what is it in 1969?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: I saw a Press report to the effect that the Australian Mutual Provident Society proposes to erect a building costing $21m at Sydney Cove.

Yes. The persons signing the balance sheet are required to state how the values of the investments are arrived at and to certify whether, in their opinion, the assets set forth in the balance sheet are in the aggregate fully of the value stated in the balance sheet, less any investment reserve fund taken into account.

The question of the most appropriate method of valuing the assets in the balance sheet of a life insurance company has been debated for many years. Substantial arguments exist in support for various methods of valuation and it is not possible to resolve the matter as simply as the question suggests. Companies are conscious of the importance of the matter as is evidenced by the recent announcement by two large life insurance companies that they have revalued their holdings of ordinary shares upwards, most of the revaluation bring utilised to provide a special bonus to certain participating policies.

It is a matter of satisfaction that no life insurance companies have failed since the Life Insurance Act came into force and that the life insurance industry is in a sound financial position. Section 48 of the Life Insurance Act provides that a company shall cause an actuary to carry out an investigation into the financial condition of its life insurance business, including an actuarial valuation of its liabilities under policies, not less frequently than every 5 years. In practice, a valuation is usually made each year. A company may not distribute to policyholders as bonuses an amount in excess of the surplus reported in the actuarial valuation. Competition amongst the companies tends to ensure the adoption, within this context, of liberal rather than conservative practices regarding the proportion of surplus distributed to participating policyholders. With regard to surrender values, the Life Insurance Act provides for payment of a minimum surrender value after a policy has been 6 years in force. Most policyholders who surrender their policies already receive more generous terms than the statutory minima. There is nothing to suggest to me that the Act is in need of amendment in regard to these matters.

The Life Insurance Act places no restraint on a company using the latest available tables of mortality provided that the actuarial liabilities, paid-up policy values and surrender values obtained are not less than those calculated according to the A 1924-29 Table, based on the experience of assured lives in the United Kingdom during the years 1924 to 1929, for ordinary policies and the AM33 Table, based on the experience of Australian male lives during the years 1932 to 1934, for industrial polices. These Tables are considered to be still suitable for the purpose of determining minimum values. The use for this purpose of the British Offices Life Table which was allowed when the Act came into force in 1946 and which is based on the experience of assured lives in the United Kingdom during the years 1863 to 1893, was terminated in 1962.

The earning rate, net of income tax, on the assets of the statutory funds maintained under the Life Insurance Act in respect of Australian and overseas business was 3.61% for 1949 and 5.85% for 1967 (the latest year for which information is at present available). The earning rate in respect of Australian business only was first calculated for 1962; it was 5.95% for 1967. It can be assumed that there has been a close correlation between movements in the earning rate in respect of Australian and overseas business and movements in the earning rate in respect of Australian business only.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice:

item.para: Since the announcement that the Canberra abattoir is to be closed, has strong opposition to the closure been expressed to him by every member of every party elected to the Australian Capital Territory Advisory Council, four local authorities, three local parliamentarians, three local newspapers, the local Chamber of Commerce, the local Trades and Labor Council and trade unions, local representatives of graziers, stock and station agents, and wholesale and retail butchers, three political parties and many community and public service associations?
Did he state, after the wholesaler who employs most of the labour there had offered a total of (170,000 for it, that no acceptable tender was received for the abattoir.
What is an acceptable tender?
Did he reject the advice of the Advisory Council that an acceptable tender was unlikely without tenant rights being given to the successful tenderer?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: There has been criticism of the Government's decision in a number of quarters. Some of the groups mentioned have expressed to me their opposition to the closure. The views expressed were taken into consideration but the Government is satisfied that its decision was soundly based and quite reasonable in the overall circumstances.

I have stated that no acceptable tender was received for the abattoir. The wholesaler described by the honourable member did not offer a total of $170,000. In fact, the amount offered was considerably lower.

This can only be determined after taking a number of factors into account such as the amount offered by the tenderer, the Commonwealth's investment in the abattoir, improvements to be effected by the tenderer, conditions of payment and rights of and conditions proposed by the tenderer.

The conditions for sale of the abattoir provided for the grant of tenant rights in improvements purchased by a successful tenderer or subsequently constructed with approval. The Advisory Council suggested that similar rights be given in the case of lease of the abattoir but having regard to all the factors it was considered quite impracticable to grant tenant rights in this case. This was expected to be taken into consideration by any tenderer.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Labour and National Service, upon notice:

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.label: 1, 2 and 3.

There is one exception, the Northern Territory Pearl Fishing Award, which does not apply to employees 'whose wages and conditions are fixed by the Northern Territory Aboriginal Ordinance'. A few Aboriginals are employed in this industry as fishing activity demands.
I understand steps are being taken to make an application to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission about the provision I have just quoted from the award.

Inspectors are appointed under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act for the purpose of securing the observance of the Act and regulations and awards of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. There are three officers of my Department in the Northern Territory who are authorised as inspectors. They are located at Darwin and Alice Springs. Their normal inspection activities are supplemented by regular tours of inspection by inspectors based in Adelaide. In addition, three inspectors are currently conducting inspections in the Northern Territory and the North of Western Australia. They are paying particular attention to employment in the pastoral industry.
Regular statistical returns covering the work of the inspectorate do not distinguish between Aboriginals and other employees.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice:

item.para: Has his attention been drawn to a submission made to the Government this year by Mr Ian G. Sykes for the XL Oil Company alleging the Government proposals would increase annual petroleum costs in Australia by $300m, jeopardise Australian equity in Australian firms and disturb Australia's balance of payments, and the further allegations, in regard to costs, that (a) Esso-B.H.P. was seeking a $1 per barrel bounty on crude oil produced for 20c, thus obtaining oil at minus 80c a barrel at a very considerable cost per head per year to Australians, (b) local affiliates of the same producer buy at some 67c a barrel above the world market price, which resulted in profits of 0.9, 1.5 and minus 0.2 per cent respectively for each year from 1963 to 1966 and (c) oil rinds have led to discounts on import prices since 1967 thus increasing cartel profits without proportionate increase in revenue?

If so, will he consider (a) legislation to require disclosure of financial status by oligopolies, (b) a capital gains tax, (c) a provision for equal access of Australian investors to equity in investment in Australia and (d) a tax evasion provision to prevent rigging of prices of raw materials between companies to avoid Australian taxes?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: Yes.

item.label: (a)
item.para: Provisions with respect to the publication and filing of accounts and financial statements of companies carrying on business in Australia are contained in the uniform companies legislation of the States and mainland Territories.

item.label: (b)
item.para: This relates to a broad policy matter which it would not be appropriate to discuss in this answer.

item.label: (c)
item.para: The Government wants local equity participation in enterprises in this country, but does not favour attempts at compulsion.

item.label: (d)
item.para: The Income Tax Assessment Act already contains a provision, section 136, which relates to businesses carried on in Australia but subject to overseas control. This -provision is designed to deal with the kind of situation postulated in the question.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice:

item.para: Do sales tax exemptions apply in respect of omnibuses whether operated by government or public authorities or by private operators?

item.label: (a)
item.para: Do exemptions apply in respect of goods used by omnibus services only if operated by government or public authorities?

item.label: (b)
item.para: If so, why do exemptions not also apply in respect of goods used by omnibus services operated by private operators?
What would be the cost of granting exemptions in respect of goods used by omnibus services operated by private operators?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: Exemption is applicable to omnibuses operated by government departments and public transport authorities. In the case of private omnibus services, exemption is limited to omnibuses, and chassis for omnibuses, with seating accommodation for not less than twelve adult passengers for use exclusively or principally in the transport of passengers for reward.

item.label: (a)
item.para: Exemption applies in respect of all goods used by government departments and authorities in the operation of omnibus services. The only exemptions specifically applicable to private omnibus services are those for omnibuses and omnibus chassis. However, in common with other business firms, private omnibus operators are also entitled to exemption in respect of equipment for use in servicing or repairing their motor vehicles, but that exemption does not extend to replacement parts, or to stationery, office furniture, etc.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The exemptions available to private omnibus operators have been determined over the years as a matter of policy,
The annual cost of granting exemption in respect of goods used by private operators in conducting their omnibus services is estimated to be of the order of $1 million.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice:

item.para: Are taxi-cabs classified as commercial vehicles in respect of State taxes and insurance premiums?
What would be the cost of classifying taxicabs as commercial vehicles in respect of sales tax?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

item.para: It is presumed that the State taxes referred to are the motor vehicle registration fees. In some States those fees are higher for taxi-cabs than for private cars because a higher scale of fees is payable for registration of hire vehicles. In other States the fees for taxi-cabs and private cars are the same.
The rates of insurance premiums for taxi-cabs, in common with those for other vehicles used for business or commercial purposes, are higher than those for private cars.

Motor cars for use as taxi-cabs, or for other business purposes, are at present taxable at the rate of 25% under a provision relating to 'motor cars designed primarily and principally for the transport of persons'. The provision also covers motor cars used for private purposes. If motor cars for use as taxi-cabs were to be taxed at 15%, the rate applicable to motor vehicles designed for commercial use, it is estimated that the loss of revenue involved would be about $1.5 million per annum if the present pattern of usage remained unchanged.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice;

item.para: How many (a) men and (b) women enlisted in the (i) Navy, (ii) Army and (iii) Air Force in each of the last 5 years?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
asked the Minister for Labour and National Service, upon notice:

item.para: Has his attention been drawn to remarks made on 7th May 1969 by the Chief Justice of the High Court to 120 law graduates at Melbourne's Monash University that lawyers and law makers should be ready to change laws before they were changed by civil disobedience, that if inappropriate laws, by-laws and regulations were not changed, agitators and law breakers would be given a claim to break the law which they should not have, that Parliament, judges and lawyers should be constantly on the watch to change the law where necessary, and, unless the law moved with the times, society was in for trouble?

If so, will he, in the light of these remarks, recommend the repeal of the National Service Act which conscripts a section of Australia's 20- year-old youths to serve and possibly die in the undeclared civil war in Vietnam?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the right honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: I have seen Press reports of the Chief Justice's address in which he is reported to have said that we should all be alert to the need to change laws which become inappropriate. He is reported to have said, also, that altering the laws requires a great deal of calm and quiet consideration and that civil disobedience was destructive because its methods are out of touch with what is fundamentally our way of life and way of maintaining society and that alterations ought not to be made under the oppression of numbers or the noise of those who are just making the noise.
I see nothing in the Chief Justice's comments which supports the repeal of the National Service Act at this time.

subdebateinfo.title: Hague Conference: Sale of Goods Conventions

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for External Affairs, upon notice:

item.para: Did Australia's principal trading partners attend the Hague Conference in April 1964 which adopted (a) the Convention relating to a Uniform Law on the International Sale of Goods and (b) the Convention relating to a Uniform Law on the Formation of Contracts for the International Sale of Goods?
Which countries have ratified the conventions?
Was the Law Council of Australia requested by the Attorney-General to consider whether Australia should accede to the Conventions and did the Council recommend that Australia should do so?
When is it expected that Australia will accede to the Conventions?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: Most of Australia's principal trading partners attended the Conference including the United States, the United Kingdom and Japan.
The United Kingdom and San Marino have ratified both conventions and Belgium has ratified the convention referred to in 1 (a) of the honourable member's question.

The Law Council of Australia was invited by the Attorney-General to express its views on the question of accession to the Convention, and it recommended that Australia should accede, subject to certain reservations.
This matter is under study.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Labour and National Service, upon notice:

item.para: Is he able to say how many deep sea divers have been killed or injured in Australian waters in the last 5 years?
When did each accident occur and what was the cause?
Are divers equipped with weapons or other devices to protect themselves against sharks and other dangerous fish?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: My Department has received the following information in response to inquiries directed to the appropriate authorities in all States and in the Northern Territory.

item.para: During the past 5 years two deep sea divers have been killed and one injured.

One death which occurred at Wollongong, New South Wales, in July 1965 resulted from asphyxiation presumed to have been caused by the diver becoming ill while at depth. The second occurred in November 1965 at Ashmore Reef, 150 miles off the north-east coast of Western Australia and was due to the illness known as the bends. The injury to the third diver occurred about 70 miles off Port Hedland in June 1968 when an anchor chain crushed his wrist and resulted in temporary paralysis of the arm.

As a general rule deep sea divers do not carry weapons or other devices to protect themselves against attack by sharks or other dangerous fish. I am informed that besides the cases I have mentioned there has been an average of one death a year over the past five years among Torres Strait Islanders who dive for pearls.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Shipping and Transport, upon notice:

item.para: Has the Australian National Line refused to divulge information concerning its development at Mort Bay, Balmain, New South Wales?
Has any evaluation been made as to the possible effects this development will have upon district amenity?
If such an evaluation has been made, has the outcome been conveyed to the Leichhardt Municipal Council?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: No. There has always been full co-operation between the authorities concerned, namely, Maritime Services Board of New South Wales, Leichhardt Municipal Council, Sydney County Council and others.
Yes.

No formal evaluation report was prepared. The Line's evaluation resulted from discussions and correspondence with the Leichhardt Municipal Council. On one occasion senior officers of the Australian National Line attended a meeting of the Leichhardt Municipal Council and answered questions about proposals for development of the area.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Shipping and Transport, upon notice:

item.para: Has the Australian National Line lodged applications for development of its loading facilities at Mort Bay, Balmain, New South Wales, with the Leichhardt Municipal Council?
Is it the intention of the Line to lodge its building plan and specifications for the development of the same area with the Leichhardt Municipal Council; if so when?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.label: 1 and 2.
item.para: Yes. The application was dealt with by Leichhardt Municipal Council on 25th July 1968, when approval was granted to the plans and application, subject to certain requirements, all of which have been accepted by the Line. The only plans which have not been submitted to the Council to date are those for the cargo shed and the single storey administrative building. These are in the course of preparation and should be submitted within the next few weeks.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Shipping and Transport, upon notice:

item.para: What are the plans of the Australian National Line for the current development being undertaken by it at Mort Bay, Balmain, New South Wales?

What are the plans or estimates of the Line in connection with (a) the size, type and siting of buildings, (b) the traffic to be generated - estimated gross inwards and outwards tonnage, as well as the flow of traffic across Balmain to and from the international container facilities at White Bay, (c) proposed hours of operation, (d) anticipated noise generation, and (e) the effects upon the living amenity of residents in the area?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: The Australian National Line is currently developing the southern shore of Mort Bay to provide a berth 435 feet in length, capable of accommodating a ship of 650 feet in length. The entire area on the southern shore of Mort Bay bounded by Mort Street, Cameron Street and Church Street right-of-way extension is being developed as an additional terminal area, having an approximate coverage of 8 acres. The wharf will be provided with a stern ramp and a travelling crane, having a capacity of 25 tons. The wharf will ultimately accommodate, in addition to Australian coastal vessels, the ship now under construction for the Australian/Japanese trade.

item.label: (a)
item.para: The buildings on the extended terminal on the southern shore of Mort Bay will consist of a cargo shed approximately 200 feet in length by 75 feet in depth and 20 feet in height, to be positioned at the foot of the rock face bordering Short Street, and an administrative office building of single storey height at the entrance to the terminal area situated in Mort Street.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The gross inward and outward traffic is estimated at 175,000 tons per annum in unit loads approximating it 5 tons per received and delivery.
There is so far no plan for the transhipment of overseas cargoes between White Bay and Mort Bay terminals.

item.label: (c)
item.para: Hours of operation will be dictated by the shipping schedule. As far as practicable ships' schedules will be programmed to coincide with normal working hours, lt must be appreciated, however, that there may be occasions when work outside normal hours might have to be undertaken.

item.label: (d) and (e)
item.para: The Line will make every endeavour to restrict terminal operations with a view to minimising all disturbances, in particular noises caused by traffic and cargo handling. In all planning which has been undertaken this factor has bees given careful consideration. The method of cargo handling in the terminal area will be by fork lift machines fitted with efficient exhaust silencers.

At that date the extent of the Albatross' (Nowra) fire was recorded in such statistics as follows:
One (1) fire involving damage to building at

A procedure has been introduced of including on the agenda of Board meetings, a list of all reports received since the previous meeting relating to fires which have caused a loss to Commonwealth property exceeding or likely to exceed $1,000 or which have some unusual feature.
